proposals.reasoning: Putting myself on the first mission lets me directly influence and take responsibility for the outcome. Between options, Charlie is widely viewed as an acceptable low‑pressure partner, and choosing Alice+Charlie avoids the too‑easy consensus around Alice+Bob that Eve and Frank were wary of. This team balances reliability with information gain: if the mission fails, suspicion narrows primarily to Charlie (since I know I’m good), and if it succeeds, both of us gain some provisional trust without giving an early free pass to a strongly consensus pair that could be hiding a coordinated evil player.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, and this pair avoids the too-easy Alice+Bob consensus while giving strong info: if it fails, suspicion focuses on Charlie; if it succeeds, we gain two provisional clears.
My teammate Charlie is on the mission, so this gives us an early chance to sabotage and create suspicion on Alice or future teams.
This avoids the overly tidy Alice+Bob consensus while still giving us solid early info; I’m fine being the lower-pressure second on the team.
Charlie is too risky for the first mission; we should avoid including them until we have more info.
Mission 1 with Alice and Charlie seems reasonably low-risk and gives us early info without rubber-stamping the Alice+Bob consensus pair.
Team fits the earlier preference to avoid the easy Alice+Bob consensus; first mission should prioritize information, and Alice+Charlie is a reasonable low‑data starting pair.

discussion.content: We’ve got almost no info yet, so I’d lean toward a team of people who seem cautious and consistent—personally I’m fine going on the first mission with someone who isn’t pushing too hard to be included.

I’m with you on avoiding anyone campaigning to be picked right away—quiet is more trustworthy than eager at this point. I’d probably start with someone who isn’t saying much plus one of us who’s been willing to sit out, just to keep the first team as low-pressure as possible.
I like the idea of keeping it low‑pressure too—Alice plus Bob feels like a reasonable, balanced starting pair to me, but I’m also fine sitting out if people are nervous about early reads.
Early on I’d rather keep it really simple: Alice and Bob as a first team sounds fine to me, and we can use the result plus how people vote around it to start building some real reads.

I’m a little wary of how quickly everyone’s lining up behind Alice + Bob with almost no pushback—I'd rather see at least one of Alice/Bob paired with someone who hasn’t been “pre‑cleared” by the group yet, even if that’s me or Charlie.
I’m okay starting with Alice + Bob, but I slightly prefer mixing it up with one of them plus Charlie so we’re not just rubber‑stamping the first consensus pair.

proposals.reasoning: This lineup balances prior info with the table’s concern about over-trusting the Mission 1 pair. Alice was on the successful first mission, so we preserve that partial trust. Diana was widely mentioned as a solid, balanced pick who wasn’t pushing too hard for any specific configuration. Including me (Bob) follows from earlier discussion where multiple players suggested adding a fresh face like Bob/Frank alongside Alice and Diana to gain more information without simply repeating the Alice–Charlie combo. This team gives us three players who have been generally pro-team, while still expanding the information pool beyond the initial mission pair.

votes.comment: I trust myself and slightly trust Charlie from Mission 1; forming a team without Charlie wastes that partial info and likely gives a higher chance of including an unrevealed evil.
I’m on the team, and getting evil presence onto early missions is valuable while the lineup still looks reasonable to the table.
My known evil ally Bob is on the team; we want him gathering trust and information, and he can choose to pass to avoid exposing himself this early.
No strong red flags on this lineup and it fits the earlier idea of keeping Alice while adding two new players for better info rather than reusing the Alice–Charlie pair.

This matches the info-gathering structure I argued for earlier (Alice + Diana + one of Bob/Frank), avoids over-trusting the Alice–Charlie pair, and is a reasonable way to get more information on Bob and Diana.
Matches the info-gathering structure I advocated (Alice plus Diana and a fresh face); reasonable balance of safety and new data without over-trusting the Mission 1 pair.

discussion.content: Given that the first mission with me and Charlie went clean, I’m inclined to trust Charlie for now, but we still need one more person who’s been acting consistently pro-good—maybe someone who didn’t hesitate to approve that first team.

I agree that Charlie looks decent for now, but one clean mission isn’t enough to clear anyone. I’d keep Charlie and add someone who was confidently pro-team last round—I'm happy to go, or Diana seems like a reasonable pick too.

Given the first mission went smoothly, I’m comfortable keeping Alice and me together and adding someone who felt pretty pro-team but not overly eager—Diana seems like a solid, balanced choice here. I’d rather avoid stacking it with people pushing too hard to get on the mission.

I’d be careful about treating a 2-person clean mission as hard proof, since an evil can easily pass the first one. I’d like to see Alice again, but with two people who weren’t on Mission 1 so we get more info and don’t over-trust Charlie too fast.

I don’t think a 2-person clean team is enough to lock in trust, so I’d like this mission to include at most one of Alice/Charlie plus two new people to get more info. I’d be fine with something like Alice, Diana, and one of Bob/Frank, and I’m okay sitting out this round.

I like the idea of not over-committing to the Mission 1 pair yet—something like Alice plus either Charlie or Diana, plus a fresh face (Bob or Eve) feels like a good balance of info and safety. I’m fine sitting out this one if that helps keep the team less suspicious.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 (Alice, Charlie) was clean, and Mission 2’s single fail strongly points to the spy being in {Bob, Diana}. Building this team keeps both Bob and Diana off while adding Eve and Frank, who are currently less suspicious to most of the table. If this mission passes, it heavily suggests that the spy (or spies) are in the group excluded here; if it fails, we know at least one spy is among Alice, Charlie, Eve, and Frank, which still gives useful information. This lineup matches the earlier consensus as the ‘safest’ and most informative team.

votes.comment: Mission 1’s Alice–Charlie pair was clean, and keeping both Bob and Diana (the only candidates for the single fail on Mission 2) off this team is the safest info-rich choice right now.
Team includes my evil teammate Charlie with no apparent suspicion, giving us a great chance to sabotage while I stay off and look cleaner.
As the only suspected spy on this team, I can choose to fail the mission while keeping Bob off the lineup, giving evil a strong chance to take the lead.
I still don’t like including Charlie; I’d rather run a team that tests exactly one of {Bob, Diana} plus new people for clearer info.
Best info-safe team: keeps both main suspects Bob and Diana off after the single-fail Mission 2, and includes only players from the clean Mission 1 plus two relatively unsuspicious additions.
Keeps both main suspects (Bob and Diana) off while reusing the clean Alice–Charlie core; best mix of safety and information for this stage.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 had exactly one fail and I know I’m good, the spy has to be either Bob or Diana, so for this next team I really want to keep both of them off and stick with people like Charlie who’s only been on a clean mission.
I get why you’re eyeing me and Diana, but if you’re that unsure, I’d rather we park Diana first and run something like Alice, Charlie, Eve, and Frank to see if the mission stays clean.

I’m fine with Bob’s suggestion of Alice, me, Eve, and Frank—Mission 1 was clean, and swapping out the two suspects from Mission 2 seems like the safest way to narrow things down. If that team fails, we’ll have a much clearer picture of where the spy actually is.

I’m a little wary of a team that’s entirely built around Mission 1 plus new people, so I’d prefer a lineup that keeps Charlie off for now and includes exactly one of Bob or me from Mission 2 to give us a clearer signal. Something like Alice, Eve, Frank, and one of Bob/Diana feels like a better info-gathering team.

From my perspective the safest play right now is exactly what Bob and Charlie suggested: run Alice, Charlie, me, and Frank, keep both Bob and Diana off this mission, and see if it stays clean. If that team passes, we’ve massively narrowed down where the spy (or spies) have to be.

I’m on board with the Alice–Charlie–Eve–Frank lineup for this one; keeping both Bob and Diana off after that single-fail Mission 2 is the cleanest way to test whether the problem was in that pair. If this team passes, we’ll have a really tight window on where the two spies are hiding.

proposals.reasoning: We’ve had two single-fail missions, and the overlaps are what worry me most. Alice has been on both failed missions, Bob was on one fail, and Charlie was on the other and is universally seen as risky to re‑include. To minimize overlap with BOTH previous failed teams at once, I want to sit out Alice, Bob, and Charlie entirely. Eve and Frank’s only failure appearance was alongside a heavily overlapping group (Alice + Charlie), so the cleaner, lower‑risk choice now is a fresh trio of me, Eve, and Frank that avoids all the main repeat suspects while still being a plausible all‑good team.

votes.comment: Given one of Bob/Diana and one of Charlie/Eve/Frank must be evil, putting Diana with BOTH Eve and Frank guarantees at least one spy on this team. We need a team that at least can be all-good, not one that’s logically impossible.
No evil on this team; if it passes, good goes to 2 wins with a clean-looking trio, which is too risky.
Cutting all of Alice, Bob, and Charlie at once feels like dodging information—this trio is too untested and ignores the overlapping suspects we still need to resolve.
Keeps both main fail-overlaps Bob and Charlie off the team; if those are where the spies are, this trio is likely clean.
Too risky to send both Diana and Frank when each was on a separate failed mission; with the score at 1-2 we need a cleaner team that avoids stacking players from both prior fails.
Diana is in a failed team pool and I know either she or Charlie is definitely evil, plus Eve/Frank are both from the other failed pool—too likely there’s at least one spy on this team.

proposals.reasoning: I know I’m good, so I want myself on the mission. Both previous fails each had exactly one fail card, and the spy on Mission 2 must be in {Alice, Bob, Diana}, while the spy on Mission 3 (from my perspective) must be in {Alice, Charlie, Frank}. The only overlap between those suspect sets is Alice; excluding her avoids the common factor in both failed missions. Choosing Bob and Diana with me also keeps us entirely away from the exact Mission 3 fail block (Alice/Charlie/Eve/Frank) except for myself, whom I trust. This team cleanly tests the Bob–Diana pair without involving Alice, and if the fail pattern was driven by Alice plus someone else, this lineup should be all-good and give us the best chance at a crucial success here.

votes.comment: Given previous fails, exactly one of Bob/Diana and exactly one of {Charlie,Eve,Frank} must be evil. This team (Eve, Bob, Diana) therefore always contains at least one spy and often two; it’s almost certainly a fail.
I’m on the team and a fail here wins the game for evil; no reason to block this proposal.
Team includes my evil teammate Bob without me, maximizing chances of a fail while keeping suspicion spread elsewhere.
Keeps both previous-fail overlaps (Alice and Charlie) off the team, and we need to start accepting plausible lineups or we’ll run out of attempts.
Given mission results, most consistent spy pairs make at least one of Bob or Diana evil; this team is too likely to contain a spy on a must‑succeed mission.

If Alice is good then this team is guaranteed to contain at least one spy, and even if Alice is evil there’s still a high chance at least one of Bob/Diana/Eve is the second spy. I don’t want both Bob and Diana together, and I still don’t trust Eve after Mission 3’s fail.

proposals.reasoning: I’m excluding Alice because she is the only player on all three previous missions, including both fails, and multiple players (including me) have expressed distrust of her. Between Bob and Eve, Bob was on the failed second mission while Eve was only on the failed third mission, so Bob is slightly more suspicious. I also strongly trust Diana based on her discussion, and I know I am good. Diana previously advocated teams drawn from herself, Eve, and me, which aligns with my own reads. Putting Diana, Eve, and myself together avoids Alice and Bob, only reuses one player from each failed team, and reflects the trust patterns that most convincingly point toward a good trio.

votes.comment: Too risky: I think at least one of {Bob,Diana} and one of {Charlie,Eve,Frank} are evil; this team has Diana plus both Eve and Frank, so it could easily contain 2 spies and lose the game.
No evil on this team; we need a spy included to have a chance to fail the mission.
This team is very likely all-good given previous mission fails, so as evil I can’t let a clean team through now.
This repeats the Diana/Eve/Frank trio that was just heavily rejected and still includes two players from the last failed mission, so it feels too risky information-wise when we’re down 1–2.

Mission 1 (Alice+Charlie) was clean, so neither Alice nor Charlie can be evil. The only pairs that fit the single-fail Missions 2 and 3 are {Bob,Frank} or {Diana,Frank}, so Frank must be evil. This team is guaranteed to contain at least one spy.

I know I’m good, and this keeps both previous overlapping fail suspects Alice and Bob off the team. If Alice is the common spy between the two fails, then only one of Diana/Eve could be evil, giving us at worst a 1‑spy team, which is as safe as we can get here.

proposals.reasoning:
As Alice, I know I’m good. From the mission results, there must be one evil in {Bob, Diana} and one evil in {Charlie, Eve, Frank}. That means any team of three including me will contain 0, 1, or 2 of those hidden evils depending on our choices. I want to pick the players who are most likely good from each suspect set while still avoiding the people most aggressively pushing me off the team, since evil knows I’m good and benefits from sidelining me.

Between Bob and Diana, I lean toward Diana: Bob has been strongly driving for the Alice/Bob/Diana trio that already failed once, which could be an evil trying to re‑enter a known compromised group. Diana has been more cautious about reusing the failure overlaps and is not hard‑pushing any specific combo that obviously benefits a particular bloc.

Between Charlie, Eve, and Frank, I lean toward Charlie: Eve and Frank are the ones explicitly pushing to exclude me from the mission, which fits an evil agenda more often than a good one when I know I’m clean. Charlie was on the first successful mission with me and is less focused on removing me outright, which slightly increases his chances of being good from my perspective.

So the highest‑confidence composition for both winning this mission and still being logically consistent with the prior results is: Alice, Charlie, and Diana.

votes.comment: Given my logic that there’s one evil in {Bob,Diana} and one in {Charlie,Eve,Frank}, this team uses the players whose behavior has seemed least agenda-driven against me (Charlie, Diana). It’s not guaranteed clean, but it’s my highest-confidence option this round.
This team includes one known evil (Charlie) and can deliver the third fail for an evil win.
I’m on the team and can sabotage; if this goes through and I fail it, evil wins the game.

Given the logic that there’s likely one evil in {Bob, Diana} and one in {Charlie, Eve, Frank}, this team pairs me (from the first set) with Charlie (from the second), which maximizes the chance we’re accidentally including both hidden evils on a must-win mission. I’d rather see a team that avoids one entire suspect group instead of mixing both.
Alice has been on both failed missions, and under the plausible assumption she’s good this team still hits a suspected spy in most role combinations; too risky this late.
As Percival I know exactly one of Charlie/Diana is evil (Morgana), so this team (Alice, Charlie, Diana) contains at least one guaranteed evil, and possibly two if Alice is also evil.

proposals.reasoning: This team keeps Alice and Charlie—who are the main overlaps across both failed missions—off the board while still directly testing the contested Bob/Diana pair in a new configuration. Mission 2 (Alice, Bob, Diana) and Mission 3 (Alice, Charlie, Eve, Frank) both failed with Alice present, so excluding her reduces repeated overlap and avoids simply rerunning a failed structure. Including Eve lets us avoid reusing the bulk of Mission 3 (we drop both Alice and Charlie) while still incorporating someone who wanted to test Bob/Diana without Alice. Frank’s preference for a Diana-centered team with either Bob or Eve is also partially satisfied by this composition, which should make it broadly acceptable while giving us fresh, high-information results about where the fails are coming from.

discussion.content: Given the two failed missions, I’m convinced at least one of Bob/Diana and at least one of Charlie/Eve/Frank are evil, so for this team we should avoid mixing from both groups—I'd rather take myself plus two from just one side, and see who’s willing to risk being grouped together.

If we buy that each fail only had one spy, the cleanest test is exactly what you said: you (Alice) plus both from one suspect pool—either you/Bob/Diana or you/Charlie/Eve—and then watch who pushes hard against which combo. Personally I’d rather see you/Bob/Diana, since re‑using a full block from the last fail (you/Charlie/Eve/Frank) feels riskier.
I’m with Bob that re‑using most of the last failed team is asking for trouble—Alice/Bob/Diana is the cleaner info test here, since if that fails we narrow evil down to that trio fast.
I really don’t like putting both Bob and Charlie back in the mix after back‑to‑back fails—something like Alice plus two from Eve/Frank/me feels a lot safer for this one.

From my point of view, the overlaps that keep failing point hardest at Alice, so I’d rather see a team like me, Bob, and Diana with Alice sitting out this round. That keeps us away from both previous exact fail combos while still testing the Bob/Diana pair without Alice muddying it.
I really don’t want Alice on this mission—given how the fails line up, I’d much rather see something like Diana, me, and either Bob or Eve.
